subject: Understanding Dyslexia
message: Hi all - a "heads up" that we have a new section here providing an introduction to our teachers and classroom assistants  - and in fact anyone with an interest in understanding the issues of dyslexia. There is a Lesson to go through and a quiz, and you are welcome to contribute to the forum  and database.

subject: Re: Housekeeping
message: Looks like this is happening now :-)

subject: Re: Housekeeping
message: You're right, Anna - there is no excuse for this, really.

subject: Housekeeping
message: Could I please make a plea to everyone to remember to clean their coffee cups after break and lunchtimes and to put them back in the cupboard, rather than expecting others to do it for you? Sorry to sound a nag but it's becoming a  bigger problem recently and we often invite guest into the staffroom and wouldn't wish them to get the wrong impression. Thanks - Anna.

subject: Moodle Teaching Tips
message: Hi all-just to say I have found some useful Tips in the Teaching with Moodle forum over on Moodle.org. Perhaps colleagues would like to go there and take a look? (Do a search for Moodle tip)

subject: Re: New teacher induction
message: I'll be looking forward to this Anna. I feel quite comfortable with Moodle but there is always something new to learn.

subject: New teacher induction
message: As part of the New Teacher Induction process, Scott and I will be running a session period 5 on Monday in AB4 to go over the basics of Moodle - while it is obligatory for teachers joining us in the new term, any one wishing to have a refresher and free that time is also welcome to join us. As we have the latest version of Moodle, there'll be a lot of interesting information to take in.

subject: New assignment training
message:
I'm offering a session next Tuesday on the new (in Moodle 2.6) assignment  features - if you're interested in annotating students' work online (and cutting down on paper!) and if you'd like to know how to set up a marking/moderating/workflow process, come along to the usual place at 4pm and I will give you a quick demo.

Happy Moodling!
Scott.

subject: Some great Moodle activity examples
replysubject: Re: Some great Moodle activity examples
message:
Hi all. Hope you enjoyed the Olympics, both the London and the Mount Orange variety!

Just to let you know there is a course Activity Examples which contains loads of working examples of glossaries, databases and quizzes that were donated over several years to a course on Moodle.org called the Exchange, curated by Paula Clough. We now have these activities here on Mount Orange for anyone to use in their own courses. Do check them out - there is something for everyone there.

subject: Cross-curricular Olympic theme
message: Hi everyone. Charles Bailey, Head of Health and Phys Ed here. You probably have seen Anna's announcement on the front page that we are allocating a country to each of our classes to get into the Olympic Spirit. After a discussion with our esteemed Principal, Anna, we thought it would be a very g1ood learning experience for the students if we used the few weeks of the Olympics to focus our lessons on particular themes related to these countries. For instance -History could look at how the Olympics came to be, with an investigation into Ancient Greece. Society and Environment are setting up a group project where students explore the economies of their chosen countries and report back to their classmates. Performing Arts are going to come up with a piece they'll present to us on our Olympic school BBQ on  Sunday August 12th as our Grand Finale. Anyone else - please post your plans here!

subject: Books again!
message:
HI all. I said I'd be back when I had investigated books. Well, I have put together our policies for Society and Environment in a Moodle book that "lives" in our office. If you want a direct link to it, take a look at the book here 

It's an easy way to deliver static content, be it words, videos, images or sound.

Now I plan to make some books for the students to use as well.

subject: Leave this page!
message: I love the new pop up that pops up if you forget to save something on a page! No more losing important stuff now!

subject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - One section at a time
replysubject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - One section at a time
message:
Yes - Book is a great new module to have:-)

I wanted to point out as well another new feature which is that in your course settings you can set it to "show only one section at a time" This is great for what they call defeating the "scroll of death" where you have loads of sections and your course page just gets longer and longer. This format has been set up  in  the Types of Sport course here if you want a look http://school.moodledemo.net/course/view.php?id=96

subject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - BOOKS!
replysubject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - BOOKS!
message: No I don't mean Books about Moodle - I mean -that when I was looking at that Activity Chooser you mentioned Heather, I noticed that we have a new module now, called Book. What was good is that I just had to click on "more help" at the bottom of the Activity chooser to get to the documentation about it, so from knowing nothing about it, I now know -well - a bit more! I will try it out in my courses and let you know how I get on with it. http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/Book_module

subject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - Activity Chooser (turn it off?)
replysubject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - Activity Chooser (turn it off?)
message: Ouch! Too much information! I can see how it's really useful for newbies but I already know how to use all these features - just thought I'd post here to let others know that if you don't want it, then you can easily go back to the "old" drop down boxes in your course by turning it off Settings>course administration. (OK, OK, only me, I know...8-.)

subject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - Activity Chooser
replysubject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - Activity Chooser
message: Another thing you might notice is that when you have editing turned on in your course you no longer get the drop downs "add a resource" or "add an activity" but instead you get a nice link "add an activity or resource" and it takes you to a helpful screen with info about how to use each item. That's known as the activity chooser and you can read more about it here http://docs.moodle.org/23/en/Course_homepage Why not try it out in our Moodle sandpit course?

subject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - drag and drop (students)
replysubject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - drag and drop (students)
message: Sure Jeffrey-students can drag and drop as well - I daresay they will figure it all out for themselves but just in case, the School councillors are going to post some help messages in their School Council course.

subject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - drag and drop
replysubject: Re: What's cool in Moodle 2.3 - drag and drop
message: Wow! That's really useful! Head spinning with ideas for forum use with my students in Society and Environment - please tell me students can drag and drop too!

subject: What's cool in Moodle 2.3
message: Hi all. Our principal Anna has asked me to give you a bit of info on our new version of Moodle that I have set up. Basically the biggest change is that you will be able to drag and drop files rather than use the file picker. (You can still use the file picker if you want!) The best way to try this out is to respond to this forum and click into the box with a big arrow and drag in a  picture:-D

subject: Re: How we made this Staffroom
replysubject: Re: How we made this Staffroom
message: Thanks Scott. Is it possible for some of us to have editing teacher rights on this (social format) course so we can also upload other policies and useful whole school documents here?

subject: How we made this Staffroom
replysubject: Re: How we made this Staffroom
message: Thought I would give a quick  bit of onsite Moodle training here as a number of you have asked me F2F: This staffroom is an example of the "social" format course format that you can get in a course by going to the course administration >edit settings. It is good for when you just want a message board basically (the Junior Hangout is similar) but I  have also added the "Social activities" block that allows us then to add other resources -like the Extra-curricular Lounge and the policy documents, in the same way we'd add resources and activities in a regular topics or weekly format course. This social format isn't suited to traditional teaching courses but it's just right for the staffroom.

message: I have C... in my World of Water class who does. (Not sure about naming names in this forum; it's possibly best if we don't to be on the safe side, even though we might be able to identify the relevant young people) C... thinks they work very well and certainly looks pretty cool in them:-D
